reviewText: $2.99. Fired it up just to check it out, thought i would do other stuff. Three and a half hours later I write this. Even if I didn't play it ever again, it would be far more worth while than the $12 or so for the average two to three hour yawn fest movie. Much more entertainment dollar value to be found here for sure.\nIt's pixely space shooty physics fun.\nYou should buy this.

reviewText: Space - The Return of the Pixxelfrazzer is a spectacular game.\nI'm always happy when one of those" games falls into my hands.\nYou know
date:
the ones you start of without a clue of what you are doing but the game pully you in nonetheless and before you know it it's morning and you didn't get any sleep.

This game defines itself through wonderful quirkiness.

One time when I was shooting at asteroids for money
recommended: one asteroid transformed into a monster and ate me.\nAnother time I was doing a quest
hoursPlayed: and when I was done the questobject suddenly killed me.\n\nSpace is never what you expect in this game
voteText: and I'm loving it.\n\nAdd to that the amount of detail besides having everything turn and eat you
helpfulPercent: and you realize this is a gem.\n\nThere's a "wiggle" upgrade in the game
votesHelpful: which is supposed to make you bullets wiggle.\nBut
votesFunny: the description text of said upgrade wiggles aswell.\n\nIt's the small things that make you wonder and smile
commentsCount: and it's doing that all the time.\nI guess part of this comes by not explaining much besides the basics
column16: so you're left with a universe of strangeness to figure out.\n\nThe controls are more on the simulation side of things in normal mode
column17:
but then there's that other mode that's great for dodging and stuff.


tl;dr
Game is random
Game is fun
Graphics are retro
column18: but with a lot of attention to detail\nMusic feels weird at first
column19:
but you grow to like it
Complete freedom - do whatever you want
Game takes you by the hand via tips flashing in every now and then
You can set the difficulty anytime
It has coop
There is a lot of things to see
You can freeze Planets."

reviewText:
Space! if you ever had the desire to punsh jelly fish with a wrecking ball in space, this might be the game for you.
This table shows the most significant features in the game:
Jelly fish hits:        result                planet        planet glows                player        player glows                wrecking ball        wrecking ball glows                asteroid        asteroid glows    Also the combination of weapons can be great.
Splitting shots with critical damage and target-seeking is one heavy thing.
And a gravity bomb! You'll just need the gravity bomb!
Last but not least there are little friendly ships who help you alot!
...and kick you out by triggering a minefield.
10/10

reviewText: Just straight-up fun. It's Asteroids with some light RPG mechanics on top and a procedurally generated world every time you play. What more could you want?\n\n-Note: Just blew up a star, collapsed into a black hole. I have no regrets.

reviewText: One of the few games I've bought for full price, and the full price was definitely worth it.  This game should be worth way more, too; it's got polished, well-constructed gameplay, and hours of fun to be had.  Far more, anyway, than some more expensive games (*cough The Order 1886 cough*).  This is one of those indie gems that you have to dig to find, but it's totally worth it.\nIt's like Asteroids but better.

reviewText: Very good game for 3 dollars. This is one of the rare indie gems I always look for when browsing Steam.\nThere isn't a plot, there are barely any instructions, this game is mainly about exploration, combination, and having fun. You can always fing something new and unexpected, a new type of asteroid that causes gravity fluctuation when you shoot it, or some kind of a bio-minefield that seems to be harvested by lasers. You can equip modifiers to your weapons that you can even combine (freezing, splitting, critting bullets anyone?).\nIf you like these kind of true sandbox games, and like to explore, for 3 dollars I can only recommend it.

reviewText:
Space – The Return of the Pixxelfrazzer is a return to old school style space exploration action games. The developer, Sørb, is a one man show and it truly shows throughout the creation of the game. I do not mean that as a negative either. It’s a simple fact. Every game design choice all of the way through to the creation of game’s engine is decided, designed and developed by Sørb. A very admirable effort is made to create a solid game and it achieves that status, solid.

It’s space exploration at it’s near pinnacle. You start the game not knowing what to do but you have a basic quest outline – attack X many space ships. You kill them. Then you’re given another quest and then another. All of the while you’re starting to realize just how gigantic space is. Space is never quite what you would imagine it to be and that is a good thing. Objects can transform, including quest objects, into all sorts of different things. It’s arguably as close as you’ll get to feeling like Han Solo in the Empires Strikes Back flying the Millennium Falcon when he tries to evade an asteroid field in order to find a safe place only to fly into the mouth of an Exogorth without knowing it. Space has so many different quirks such as this it’s hard not to appreciate the amount of effort put into its design.

The variety of weapons, quests, planets, etc. are incredible creating a game world where there is seemingly always something to see and to enjoy. The sound and graphics are old school and therefore may not appeal to players demanding the latest and greatest but for someone who can appreciate the fact that sometimes less is more it is easy to look past and perhaps even appreciate more. Other than that there really isn’t much to knock about the game and that’s being fair. It’s not the greatest game of all time but there’s more than enough content here to spend a few hours with an enjoyable title.

Sadly with just 17 Steam reviews and an estimated 394 – 1858 total owners (according to SteamSpy), Space – The Return of the Pixxelfrazzer has been a criminally overlooked title that is yearning to be played.

For similar reviews and our popular daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

reviewText:
There's a very charming game of discovery and exploration in here - I think - I've hit a few snags but I'm slowly figuring-out what's going on.

In my first run I met a triangle who wanted to be my friend - some higsaw pieces who I reunited and some octopus-looking-things which glowed for - well - I've no idea but I intend to find out!

My only grumble is that dying = losing money which would be OK if that wasn't money 'lost forever' from that 'universe' - meaning your progress in that 'universe' was just stunted a bit.  Every reload is a 'new universe' too - which solves the money thing but then breaks the exploration thing and

I'm still enjoying it ;0
